title: 106_s1458
content: The Act titled "Teenage Pregnancy Reduction Act of 1999" evaluates effective programs for preventing adolescent pregnancy. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will evaluate existing programs aimed at preventing adolescent pregnancy to determine their effectiveness, factors contributing to their success, and feasibility of replication in other locations. This evaluation includes programs not funded by the Federal Government. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will evaluate adolescent pregnancy prevention programs with input from various agencies and organizations with expertise in program evaluation. The evaluation design will consider programs in different regions and populations served. The Secretary will define measures of effectiveness for evaluating adolescent pregnancy prevention programs, including factors specific to different demographics and gender. Funding for evaluation will be based on scientific peer review involving experts from public and private entities. The evaluation of adolescent pregnancy prevention programs will be completed by December 1, 2004, with a report submitted to Congress and the Secretary containing findings and recommendations for future programs. The Secretary will disseminate the findings and recommendations to various entities including prevention program administrators, public and private entities providing financial support, medical associations, public health services, social work services, and school administrators. Authorization of Appropriations: $3,500,000 authorized for each fiscal year from 2000 to 2002, with additional funding as needed for fiscal years 2003 to 2005. SEC. 3. ONE-TIME INCENTIVE GRANTS FOR EFFECTIVE PREVENTION PROGRAMS. The Secretary may make a one-time grant to entities with effective prevention programs to assist with operating expenses. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2004 through 2006. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. Prevention programs under this Act encompass various approaches such as advocating abstinence, providing family planning services, fostering academic achievement, mentoring, job training, counseling, and social events. The Act applies to prevention programs regardless of their specific focus. The term "prevention program" refers to a program aimed at preventing adolescent pregnancy. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
